Answer A: By moving the deactivating switch from the DISARM position to the ARM position while monitoring the civil emergency frequency with a communications receiver at five minutes after the hour.
Answer B: By activating the 5 g switch and turning the unit on at five minutes after the hour.
Answer C: By tuning a communications receiver to the civil emergency frequency and activating the ELT momentarily within five minutes after the hour.
Explanation (General): Operation of an ELT is verified by tuning a communications receiver to the emergency frequency of 121.5 or 406 MHz and activating the transmitter for no more than three audible sweeps. The test must be conducted within the first five minutes after any hour. If the ELT must be operated outside of this time frame, you should contact the control tower before conducting this test.

Question: Static dischargers help eliminate radio interference by dissipating static electricity into the atmosphere at
Answer C: high current levels.
Explanation (General): Static dischargers are mounted on the trailing edges of aircraft control surfaces to conduct charges of static electricity into the atmosphere before they build up enough voltage to cause a high current to flow and cause radio interference. By the proper design and location of these dischargers, the static charges will be dissipated while its current level is low.

Question: An aircraft antenna installation must be grounded
Answer C: to the radio rack.
Explanation (General): When an aircraft radio antenna installation is required to be grounded, it is grounded to the airframe structure.

Question: VHF radio signals are commonly used in
Answer C: both VOR navigation and ATC communications.
Explanation (General): Very High Frequency (VHF) radio transmissions operate in the 118.000 to 135.975 megahertz range. This frequency range is used for air traffic control (ATC) communications and Very-high-frequency Omni Range (VOR) navigation.

Question: On modern large aircraft, what electronic device typically monitors flight parameters and performs autopilot functions?
Answer C: Control/display unit.
Explanation (General): Large aircraft have many sophisticated electronic control devices. The Flight Management Computer (FMC) monitors flight parameters and performs autopilot functions. It regulates the movement of the control surface actuators which control the stabilizers, elevators, rudders, speed brakes, and spoilers.

Question: In the landing configuration GPWS typically monitors the radio (radar) altimeter; air data computer; instrument landing system; and
Answer C: spoiler, slat, and stabilizer positions.
Explanation (General): The Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) senses the nearness of the ground and warns the pilot if the aircraft has gotten too near the ground when it is not in a configuration for landing. It does this by monitoring the radar altimeter to determine the actual height above the ground.|It also monitors the air data computer, instrument landing system, and landing gear and flap position to determine if the aircraft is properly configured for its distance from the ground. If it is too near the ground for its location or configuration, the system will warn the pilot.

Question: In general, the purpose of an aircraft transponder is to
Answer A: continually transmit heading, speed, and rate of climb/decent etc. information to ATC.
Answer B: monitor aircraft speed, heading, altitude, and attitude whenever the autopilot system is engaged.
Answer C: receive an interrogation signal from a ground station and automatically send a reply back.
Explanation (General): An Air Traffic Control (ATC) transponder is a special radio transceiver that receives an interrogation signal from an ATC radar and automatically replies with a coded signal. The coded response to the ground station interrogation allows the controller to identify the aircraft.

Question: When an antenna is installed, it should be fastened
Answer A: to the primary structure at the approximate intersection of the three aircraft axes.
Answer B: with a reinforcing doubler on each side of the aircraft skin.
Answer C: so that loads imposed are transmitted to the aircraft structure.
Explanation (General): An antenna must be installed on an aircraft in such a way that the loads imposed are transmitted into the aircraft structure.

Question: After an automatic direction finding antenna has been installed, the
Answer C: transceiver must be compensated.
Explanation (General): When an automatic direction finder is installed on a particular type of aircraft for the first time, it is important that the loop antenna be checked for quadrantal error.|Quadrantal error is the error caused by the metal in the aircraft structure distorting the electromagnetic field of the received signal.|Quadrantal error causes azimuth inaccuracies, which are greatest between the four cardinal points with respect to the center line of the aircraft.

Question: Doublers are used when antennas are installed to
Answer B: prevent oil canning of the skin.
Answer C: reinstate the structural strength of the aircraft skin.
Explanation (General): A doubler is used under an antenna when it is installed on an aircraft skin to replace the strength in the structure that was lost when the hole was cut for mounting the antenna.

Question: One antenna can be used for the radio range and standard broadcast bands in light aircraft because the
Answer C: antenna length may be electronically adjusted.
Explanation (General): One antenna can be used on light aircraft to receive both the low-frequency radio range and the standard broadcast bands.|The frequency range of these two types of radio transmissions are so close together that one antenna can effectively receive both signals.

Question: What characteristics of the installation of a rigid antenna on a vertical stabilizer should be evaluated?
Answer C: Flutter and vibration.
Explanation (General): When any rigid antenna is mounted on a vertical stabilizer, the flutter and vibration characteristics must be carefully evaluated.|An antenna can change the resonant frequency of the vertical surface.

Question: A gasket or sealant is used between the antenna mast and fuselage skin
Answer A: to prevent the entry of moisture.
Answer C: to prevent abrasion between the antenna mast and fuselage skin.
Explanation (General): A gasket or sealant is used between a radio antenna mast and the fuselage skin to prevent the entry of moisture into the fuselage.

Question: The preferred location of a VOR antenna on light aircraft is on
Answer A: the bottom of the fuselage and as far forward as possible.
Answer B: top of the cabin with the apex of the V pointing forward.
Answer C: top of the vertical stabilizer.
Explanation (General): The preferred location for a VOR antenna on a single-engine aircraft is on top of the cabin, with the apex of the V pointing forward.

Question: The purpose of a localizer is to
Answer A: set the airplane on the proper approach angle to the runway.
Answer B: indicate the distance the airplane is from the end of the runway.
Answer C: align the airplane with the center of the runway.
Explanation (General): The function of a localizer in an Instrument Landing System (ILS) is to align the aircraft with the center line of the instrument runway.

Question: (Refer to Figure 15.) What is the approximate drag load on an antenna with a frontal area of .125 square feet installed on an aircraft with a speed of 225 MPH?
Answer C: 2.080 pounds.
Explanation (General): This computation is described in AC 43.13-2A.|The constant 0.000327 is multiplied by the frontal area of the antenna (in this case, 0.125 square foot). This quantity is multiplied by the square of the never-exceed speed of the aircraft which is 225 MPH.|D = 0.000327 x 0.125 x 225^2 = 2.069 pounds

Question: (Refer to Figure 15.) What is the approximate drag load on an antenna with a frontal area of .137 square feet installed on an aircraft with a speed of 275 MPH?
Answer C: 3.592 pounds.
Explanation (General): This computation is described in AC 43.13-2A.|The constant 0.000327 is multiplied by the frontal area of the antenna (in this case, 0.137 square foot). This quantity is multiplied by the square of the never-exceed speed of the aircraft which is 275 MPH.|D = 0.000327 x 0.137 x 275^2 = 3.3879 pounds

Question: A DME antenna should be located in a position on the aircraft that will
Answer A: not be blanked by the wing when the aircraft is banked.
Answer C: eliminate the possibility of the DME locking on a station.
Explanation (General): To prevent an interruption in DME operation, the antenna must be located in a position that will not be blanked by the wing when the aircraft is banked.

Question: When bending coaxial cable, the bend radius should be at least
Answer A: 10 times the diameter of the cable.
Answer B: 15 times the diameter of the cable.
Answer C: 20 times the diameter of the cable.
Explanation (General): Because it is essential that the center conductor of a coaxial cable remain in its exact center, coax should not be bent with a radius of less than 10 times its diameter.

Question: When installing a DME antenna, it should be aligned with the
Answer C: centerline on the airplane.
Explanation (General): A DME antenna should be mounted on the center line of the belly of an airplane.

Question: (Refer to Figure 16.) Which of the antennas shown is a typical DME antenna?
Explanation (General): The antenna shown in 1 is a DME or a radar beacon transponder antenna.|The antenna shown in 2 is a glide slope antenna.|The antenna shown in 3 is a VOR and localizer antenna.|The antenna shown in 4 is a VHF communications antenna.

Question: (Refer to Figure 16.) Which of the antennas shown is a typical glideslope antenna?
Explanation (General): The antenna shown in 2 is a glide slope antenna.

Question: The addition of avionics and associated antenna systems forward of the CG limit will affect
Answer C: useful load and maximum gross weight.
Explanation (General): The installation of avionics equipment and its associated antenna, ahead of the CG limit, will affect the empty weight of the aircraft, its CG, and its useful load.|When such equipment is installed, a new weight and balance record must be made showing the change in the empty weight and empty-weight CG of the aircraft. The addition of avionics equipment will decrease the useful load of the aircraft.

Question: How much clearance from the seat bottom is required when installing radio equipment under a seat?
Answer B: No set minimum as long as the equipment receives adequate cooling and damage protection.
Answer C: 1 inch with the seat occupied and subjected to maximum downward seat spring deflection.
Explanation (General): When installing radio equipment under an aircraft seat, there must be one inch of clearance between the equipment and the bottom of the seat when it is occupied and subjected to a downward force of 1,122 pounds. This load is found by multiplying the 170-pound nominal weight of an occupant by a load factor of 6.6.

Question: The purpose of a glideslope system is to
Answer A: provide for automatic altitude reporting to air traffic control.
Answer B: indicate the distance the airplane is from the end of the runway.
Answer C: assist the pilot in making a correct angle of descent to the runway.
Explanation (General): The glide slope system is the part of an Instrument Landing System (ILS) that allows a pilot to make the correct angle of descent to the instrument runway during an approach.

Question: Fuel jettisoning is usually accomplished
Answer A: through a common manifold and outlet in each wing.
Answer B: by gravity flow into the outboard wing tanks and overboard through a common outlet in each wing.
Answer C: through individual outlets for each tank.
Explanation (General): Fuel jettisoning is usually accomplished by a fuel dump manifold, which connects the dumpable fuel tanks to the dump valves and to a fixed or extendable dump chute in each wing.

Question: The primary purpose of an aircraft's fuel jettison system is to quickly achieve a
Answer C: reduced fire hazard.
Explanation (General): Some aircraft are allowed to have a higher takeoff weight than is allowed for landing. These aircraft must have a fuel jettison system that allows the pilot or flight engineer to safely dump, or jettison, enough fuel to reduce the aircraft weight to its allowable landing weight.

Question: (1) The fuel jettison valve must be designed to allow flight personnel to close the valve during any part of the jettisoning operation.|(2) During the fuel jettisoning operation, the fuel must discharge clear of any part of the airplane.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer A: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Answer C: neither No. 1 nor No. 2 is true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. The fuel-jettisoning valve must be designed to allow flight personnel to close the valve during any part of the jettisoning operation.|Statement (2) is also true. During the fuel-jettisoning operation, the fuel must discharge clear of any part of the airplane.

Question: Which of the following is employed to maintain lateral stability when jettisoning fuel?
Answer C: Two interconnected systems.
Explanation (General): Lateral stability during fuel jettisoning is maintained by having two separate and independent jettisoning systems. There is one system for each side of the aircraft.

Question: A fuel jettison system is required under certain conditions if the maximum takeoff weight exceeds the maximum landing weight. What regulations cover the requirements of fuel jettisoning?
Answer B: Federal Aviation Regulation Part 23, 25 and CAM 4b.
Answer C: Federal Aviation Regulation Part 21, 43 and CAM 8.
Explanation (General): The regulations governing fuel jettisoning systems are covered in Federal Aviation Regulations Parts 23 and 25, and in the Civil Air Regulations Part 04 for aircraft that were certificated by the Civil Aeronautics Administration before the formation of the FAA.

Question: Fuel is moved overboard in most fuel jettison systems by
Answer C: gravity and engine-driven fuel pumps.
Explanation (General): Fuel is moved overboard in a jettison system by boost pumps located in the fuel tanks.

Question: Fuel jettisoning past the limits prescribed by Federal Aviation Regulations is usually prevented by
Answer A: closely monitoring the fuel quantity and turning off the fuel dump switch(es).
Answer B: dump limit valves or a low-level circuit.
Answer C: standpipes in the fuel tanks.
Explanation (General): Fuel tanks whose fuel can be jettisoned are equipped with a dump limit switch that will shut off the flow to the dump chute if the pressure drops below that needed to supply the engine with adequate fuel, or when the tank level reaches a preset dump shutoff level.

Question: Which procedure must be followed when defueling aircraft with sweptback wings?
Answer A: Defuel all the tanks at one time.
Answer B: Defuel the inboard wing tanks first.
Answer C: Defuel the outboard wing tanks first.
Explanation (General): Unless the service manual specifies otherwise, the outboard fuel tanks on an aircraft with swept back wings should be defueled first.|This procedure minimizes the twisting effect on the wing caused by the fuel being located behind the wing attachment points on the fuselage.

Question: (Refer to Figure 17.) What is the purpose of the pump crossfeed valve?
Answer A: Balance the fuel in the tanks.
Answer B: Allow operation of engines from one tank.
Answer C: Allow operation of the left engine when the right fuel-boost pump is inoperative.
Explanation (General): The pump cross-feed valve shown here allows both engines to operate from either of the two tanks.

Question: Normal fuel crossfeed system operation in multiengine aircraft
Answer A: calls for jettisoning of fuel overboard to correct lateral instability.
Answer B: reduces contamination and/or fire hazards during fueling or defueling operations.
Answer C: provides a means to maintain a balanced fuel load condition.
Explanation (General): Multiengine aircraft normally have fuel tanks located in widely separated parts of the aircraft. A crossfeed fuel system allows fuel to be used from any tank by any of the engines. This allows a balanced fuel load to be maintained.

Question: What is the primary purpose of the crossfeed system?
Answer A: To allow the feeding of any engine from any tank.
Answer B: To allow the feeding of fuel from one tank for defueling.
Answer C: To provide automatic refueling of a tank to any desired level.
Explanation (General): A cross-feed system allows any engine on a multiengine aircraft to be fed from any tank.|This can be used to maintain a balanced fuel load.

Question: Fuel system components must be bonded and grounded in order to
Answer C: retard galvanic corrosion.
Explanation (General): Aircraft fuel-system components must be bonded to the aircraft structure and must be grounded in order to prevent a buildup of static electricity.|Static electricity could cause a spark and a fire.

Question: A typical large transport aircraft fuel manifold system allows how many of the following?|1. All tanks can be serviced through a single connection.|2. Any engine can be fed from any tank.|3. All engines can be fed from all tanks simultaneously.|4. A damaged tank can be isolated from the rest of the fuel system.
Explanation (General): In a large aircraft manifold fuel system, all tanks can be serviced through a single connection, any engine can be fed from any tank, all engines can be fed from all tanks simultaneously, and a damaged tank can be isolated from the rest of the fuel system.

Question: The use of turbine fuels in aircraft has resulted in some problems not normally associated with aviation gasolines. One of these problems is
Answer A: increasing viscosity of fuel as fuel temperature lowers at altitude.
Answer C: microbial contaminants.
Explanation (General): Microbial contamination is a fuel system problem that is associated with the higher viscosity fuel used in turbine engine aircraft.|Turbine engine fuel holds water more readily than gasoline. Microorganisms live in this water and form a scum which clogs the fuel filters, lines, and fuel controls. The scum holds water against the fuel tank structure and causes tank corrosion.

Question: What is used in many aircraft to prevent bubbles in the fuel after it leaves the tank when atmospheric pressure is lower than fuel vapor pressure?
Answer C: Boost pumps.
Explanation (General): Boost pumps installed in many aircraft fuel tanks have an agitator on their shaft along with the impeller. The agitator causes bubbles in the fuel to be released into the tank before the fuel is forced into the fuel lines. The boost pumps hold a pressure on the fuel in the lines to prevent additional vapors from forming.

Question: Which of the following precautions is most important during refueling operations?
Answer A: All outside electrical sources must be disconnected from the aircraft.
Answer B: Fuel to be used must be appropriately identified.
Answer C: All electrical switches must be in OFF position.
Explanation (General): It is extremely important when fueling an aircraft that the fuel be properly identified. The use of fuel with a lower than allowed octane or performance rating can cause detonation which can destroy an engine.|A number of airplanes have been destroyed by the inadvertent fueling of a reciprocating engine aircraft with turbine-engine fuel. Turbine-engine fuel will cause severe detonation when a reciprocating engine is operated at takeoff power.

Question: Before fueling an aircraft by using the pressure fueling method, what important precaution should be observed?
Answer A: The truck pump pressure must be correct for that refueling system.
Answer B: The truck pump pressure must be adjusted for minimum filter pressure.
Answer C: The aircraft's electrical system must be on to indicate quantity gauge readings.
Explanation (General): Before fueling an aircraft, it is important that the fuel-truck pump pressure be correct for the refueling system.|Some systems, such as that used on the Boeing 727, require a maximum fuel delivery pressure of 50 psi. The delivery pressure varies with the different aircraft.

Question: What flight safety-related advantage does a pressure fueling system provide?
Answer A: Keeps the aircraft within weight and balance limitations.
Answer B: Reduces the chances for fuel contamination.
Answer C: Reduces the time required for fueling.
Explanation (General): Pressure fueling of an aircraft reduces the chances of fuel contamination, as well as reducing the danger of static electricity igniting fuel vapors.

Question: Aircraft pressure fueling systems instructional procedures are normally placarded on the
Answer B: lower wing surface adjacent to the access door.
Answer C: aircraft ground connection point.
Explanation (General): Pressure-fueling instructional procedures are normally placarded on the fuel control panel access door.|No one should fuel an aircraft with a fuel pressure fueling system unless he or she has been thoroughly checked out on the procedure.

Question: Pressure fueling of aircraft is usually accomplished through
Answer A: pressure connections on individual fuel tanks.
Answer B: at least one single point connection.
Answer C: individual fuel tank overwing and/or fuselage access points.
Explanation (General): A manifold fuel system allows an aircraft to be fueled by the pressure fueling method. All of the tanks can be fueled at the same time through a single manifold connection. This reduces the fueling time, minimizes the chance of contamination, and minimizes the buildup of static electrical charges.

Question: Which of the following may be used for the repair of fuel leaks on most integral fuel tanks?
Answer C: Riveting and resealing.
Explanation (General): Since an integral fuel tank is a part of the aircraft structure, it is repaired by riveting, and resealing the repaired area.

Question: How is the outlet fuel pressure regulated on a submerged, single-speed, centrifugal-type fuel pump?
Answer A: By the engine-driven pump's design and internal clearance.
Answer B: By the first check valve downstream from the pump.
Answer C: By the pump's design and internal clearances.
Explanation (General): The outlet fuel pressure produced by a submerged, single-speed, centrifugal-type fuel pump is determined by the pump's design and its internal clearances and characteristics.

Question: What is one purpose of a fuel tank vent?
Answer C: To decrease tank internal air pressure.
Explanation (General): A fuel-tank vent maintains atmospheric pressure on top of the fuel in the tank to provide for proper fuel flow from the tank to the engine.

Question: When inspecting a removable rigid fuel tank for leaks, what procedure should be followed?
Answer A: pressurize the tank with air and brush with soapy water.
Answer B: fill the tank with water and pressurize with air and brush with soapy water.
Answer C: pressurize the tank with air and submerge in water to locate leaks.
Explanation (General): After a removable rigid fuel tank has been repaired, it should be pressurized with no more than 1/2-psi air pressure, and all seams and the repaired area should be inspected by brushing on liquid soap or a soap bubble solution to check for any indication of leaks.

Question: If it is necessary to enter an aircraft's fuel tank, which procedure should be avoided?
Answer A: Continue purging the tank during the entire work period.
Answer B: Station an assistant outside the fuel tank access to perform rescue operations if required.
Answer C: Conduct the defueling and tank purging operation in an air-conditioned building.
Explanation (General): You are asked which procedure should be avoided.|All defueling and purging must be done outside, not in any building, air-conditioned or otherwise.

Question: What is the recommended practice for cleaning a fuel tank before welding?
Answer B: Flush the inside of the tank with clean water.
Answer C: Steam clean the tank interior.
Explanation (General): Before a gasoline tank is welded, it should be washed out with hot water and a detergent. Then, live steam should be passed through the tank for about a half hour.|This treatment vaporizes and removes any residual fuel that may be left in the tank.

Question: An aircraft's integral fuel tank is
Answer A: usually located in the bottom of the fuselage.
Answer B: a part of the aircraft structure.
Answer C: a self-sealing tank.
Explanation (General): An aircraft integral fuel tank is actually a portion of the aircraft structure that is sealed off and is used as a fuel tank.

Question: Which gas is used for purging an aircraft fuel tank?
Answer C: Carbon monoxide.
Explanation (General): Carbon dioxide can be used to purge an aircraft fuel tank of fuel vapors.

Question: Why is the main fuel strainer located at the lowest point in the fuel system?
Answer A: It traps any small amount of water that may be present in the fuel system.
Answer B: It provides a drain for residual fuel.
Answer C: It filters and traps all micro-organisms that may be present in the fuel system.
Explanation (General): One reason for having the main fuel strainer of an aircraft located at the lowest point in the fuel system is so it will trap and hold any small amount of water that is in the fuel system.

Question: The purpose of a diaphragm in a vane-type fuel pump is to
Answer A: equalize fuel pressure at all speeds.
Answer B: vary fuel pressure according to throttle setting.
Answer C: compensate fuel pressures to altitude changes.
Explanation (General): The diaphragm in a compensated vane-type fuel pump is used to compensate the fuel pressure for altitude changes.|It maintains the fuel pressure a constant amount above the pressure of the ambient air.

Question: When moving the mixture control on a normally operating engine into the idle cutoff position, engine RPM should
Answer A: slightly increase before the engine starts to die.
Answer B: slightly decrease and then drop rapidly.
Answer C: remain the same until the cutoff is effected, then drop rapidly.
Explanation (General): An engine normally uses an idling fuel-air mixture richer than that which produces the most efficient burning.|When the mixture control is moved into the IDLE CUTOFF position, the mixture passes through the ratio that produces the best burning. The RPM picks up a few RPMs before it drops off completely.

Question: Entrained water in aviation turbine fuel is a hazard because of its susceptibility to freezing as it passes through the filters. What are common methods of preventing this hazard?
Answer A: Micromesh fuel strainers and fuel heater.
Answer B: High-velocity fuel pumps and fuel heater.
Answer C: Anti-icing fuel additives and fuel heater.
Explanation (General): Turbine engine fuel may have moisture entrained in it that will condense out and freeze on the fuel filters. This ice will shut off the flow of fuel to the engines.|To eliminate this danger, anti-icing additives may be put in the turbine fuel to lower the freezing temperature of the water and prevent its freezing on the filters.|Most jet transport aircraft have fuel heaters, or heat exchangers, that use engine compressor bleed air or engine oil to raise the temperature of the fuel enough that it will not freeze on the filters.

Question: As a general rule, which statement is true regarding fuel leaks?
Answer A: Stains, seeps, and heavy seeps are not flight hazards.
Answer B: All fuel leaks regardless of location or severity are considered a hazard to flight.
Answer C: Stains, seeps, and heavy seeps, (in addition to running leaks) are considered flight hazards when located in unvented areas of the aircraft.
Explanation (General): Any fuel leaking from an aircraft fuel tank can constitute a safety of flight situation under certain conditions.|A stain, seep, or even a heavy seep is not considered to be a flight hazard unless it is in an unvented area where the fumes can collect and cause a fire hazard. Any type of leak that allows fuel vapors to accumulate must be repaired before the aircraft can be released for flight.

Question: The presence of fuel stains around a fuel nozzle would indicate
Answer C: clogged fuel nozzle.
Explanation (General): A clogged fuel-injection nozzle will allow the fuel to escape through the air bleed holes in the side of the nozzle.|There will be fuel stains on the cylinder head around the clogged nozzle.

Question: What should be used to inert an integral fuel tank before attempting repairs?
Answer C: Steam.
Explanation (General): Before working inside an integral fuel tank, you should inert it (replace the gasoline fumes with an inert gas).|Integral fuel tanks can be inerted by filling them with carbon dioxide (CO(2)).

Question: What should be used to remove flux from an aluminum tank after welded repairs?
Answer B: 5 percent solution of nitric or sulfuric acid.
Answer C: Mild solution of soap and warm water.
Explanation (General): Promptly, upon completion of welding, wash the inside and outside of the tank with liberal quantities of hot water and then drain.|Next, immerse the tank in either a 5% nitric-acid or 5% sulfuric-acid solution.

Question: What method would be used to check for internal leakage of a fuel valve without removing the valve from the aircraft?
Answer A: Place the valve in the OFF position, drain the strainer bowl, and with boost pump on, watch to see if fuel flows to the strainer bowl.
Answer B: Remove fuel cap(s), turn boost pump(s) on, and watch for bubbling in the tanks.
Answer C: Apply regulated air pressure on the downstream side of the fuel pump and listen for air passing through the valve.
Explanation (General): Internal leakage in a fuel valve can be checked by placing the valve in the OFF position and then draining the fuel strainer bowl.|Turn the fuel-tank boost pump on. If fuel flows into the empty strainer bowl, the valve has an internal leak.

Question: Why are jet fuels more susceptible to water contamination than aviation gasoline?
Answer A: Jet fuel has a higher viscosity than gasoline.
Answer B: Jet fuel is lighter than gasoline; therefore, water is more easily suspended.
Answer C: Condensation is greater because of the higher volatility of jet fuels.
Explanation (General): Jet fuels have a higher viscosity than aviation gasoline. Because of this higher viscosity, contaminants such as water remain suspended in the fuel and do not settle out into the fuel tank sumps.

Question: When installing a rigid fuel line, 1/2 inch in diameter, at what intervals should the line be supported?
Answer C: 16 inches.
Explanation (General): Rigid fuel lines installed in an aircraft should be supported by clamps or brackets at the distances specified in AC 43.13-1B.|For a 1/2-inch line, the supports should be installed every 16 inches along the run of the line.

Question: The probe of a capacitance-type fuel level gauge is essentially a
Answer B: capacitor with fuel and air acting as one plate.
Answer C: capacitor with fuel and air acting as a dielectric.
Explanation (General): A capacitance-type, fuel-quantity-indicating system uses a capacitor (condenser) as a tank probe. Fuel and air are the dielectric between the plates of the probe.

Question: Which statement concerning an electronic capacitance-type fuel quantity indicating system is true?
Answer A: It has no moving parts in the tank.
Answer B: It has two tubes separated by an electronic field in the tank.
Answer C: It utilizes a variable capacitor to indicate the fuel tank capacity.
Explanation (General): The capacitance-type, fuel-quantity-indicating system uses probes with no moving parts inside the tank.|These probes are made of two concentric tubes that serve as the plates of a capacitor. Fuel and air act as the dielectric.

Question: What type of remote-reading fuel quantity indicating system has several probes installed in each fuel tank?
Answer C: Direct reading.
Explanation (General): The electronic (capacitance-type), remote-reading, fuel-quantity-indicating system has several probes installed in each fuel tank.|The total capacity of the probes accurately relates to the amount of fuel in the tank.

Question: Which aircraft fuel quantity indicating system incorporates a signal amplifier?
Answer C: Electrical.
Explanation (General): An electronic (capacitance-type) fuel-quantity-indicating system incorporates a signal amplifier.

Question: A drip gauge may be used to measure
Answer A: the amount of fuel in the tank.
Answer B: system leakage with the system shut down.
Answer C: fuel pump diaphragm leakage.
Explanation (General): A drip gauge is used to measure the quantity of fuel in a fuel tank when the aircraft is on the ground.|The drip gauge is pulled down from the bottom of the tank until fuel begins to drip from its end. The quantity of fuel in the tank is indicated on the gauge by the amount the gauge is pulled from the tank before it begins to drip.

Question: The electronic-type fuel quantity indicating system consists of a bridge circuit,
Answer A: an amplifier, an indicator, and a tank unit.
Answer B: a tank, an amplifier, and an indicator.
Answer C: a tank unit, a tank, and an amplifier.
Explanation (General): An electronic (capacitance-type), fuel-quantity-indicating system contains the following parts:|Capacitor probes, mounted in the tanks.|A bridge circuit to measure the capacity of the probes.|An amplifier to increase the amplitude of the signal from the bridge circuit to a value high enough to drive the indicator.|An indicator mounted in the instrument panel to show the amount of fuel in the tanks.

Question: A probe or a series of probes is used in what kind of fuel quantity indicating system?
Answer C: Synchro.
Explanation (General): Probes, which are capacitors, are used as the fuel-quantity-sensing elements in a capacitor-type, fuel-quantity-indicating system.

Question: Why is the capacitance fluid quantity indicating system more accurate in measuring fuel level than a mechanical type?
Answer A: Only one probe and one indicator are necessary for multiple tank configurations.
Answer B: It measures in gallons and converts to pounds.
Answer C: It measures by weight instead of volume.
Explanation (General): The electronic (capacitor-type), fuel-quantity-indicating system is more accurate than other types of systems used for measuring fuel quantity.|These systems use several capacitor-type probes extending across each tank from top to bottom. When the attitude of the aircraft changes, fuel rises in some probes and lowers in others. The total capacitance of all probes remains constant as the aircraft attitude changes. This causes the fuel-level indication to remain constant as attitude changes.|The dielectric constant of the fuel changes with its density. Therefore, the system is able to determine the mass (weight) of the fuel rather than its volume.

Question: One advantage of electrical and electronic fuel quantity indicating systems is that
Answer A: the indicators are calibrated in gallons; therefore, no conversion is necessary.
Answer B: only one transmitter and one indicator are needed regardless of the number of tanks.
Answer C: several fuel tank levels can be read on one indicator.
Explanation (General): Two important advantages of the electronic and electrical fuel-quantity-indicating systems are that the indicator can be located any distance from the tanks and the fuel levels of several tanks can be read on one indicator.

Question: A fuel totalizer is a component which indicates the
Answer A: total amount of fuel being consumed by all engines.
Answer B: amount of fuel in any given tank.
Answer C: amount of fuel in all tanks.
Explanation (General): A fuel totalizer is a single instrument that gives an indication of the total quantity of the fuel remaining on board the aircraft.|The totalizer adds the quantities of the fuel in all of the tanks.

Question: What is the dielectric (nonconducting material) in a capacitance-type fuel quantity indicating system?
Answer C: Fuel and air in the tank.
Explanation (General): The dielectric used in the tank probes of a capacitor-type, fuel-quantity-indicating system is the fuel and the air in the tank above the fuel.|Fuel has a dielectric constant of approximately two. Air has a dielectric constant of one.

Question: A capacitance-type fuel quantity indicating system measures fuel in
Answer C: gallons.
Explanation (General): A capacitance-type, fuel-quantity-indicating system measures the density of the fuel (the dielectric constant of the fuel changes with its density). It indicates the quantity of fuel in pounds rather than in gallons.

Question: What are the four general types of fuel quantity gauges?|1. Sight glass.|2. Mechanical.|3. Electrical.|4. Electronic.|5. Bourdon tube.|6. Vane-type transmitter.|7. Litmus indicator.|8. Direct-reading static pressure type.
Explanation (General): The types of fuel-quantity-indicating systems used in aircraft are sight glasses, mechanical systems, electrical systems, and electronic systems.

Question: How does temperature affect fuel weight?
Answer A: Cold fuel is heavier per gallon.
Answer B: Warm fuel is heavier per gallon.
Answer C: Temperature has no effect.
Explanation (General): The density of aircraft fuel varies with its temperature. The colder the fuel, the more pounds of fuel there are in a gallon. Aircraft engines use fuel on the basis of its weight rather than its volume.

Question: One advantage of electrical and electronic fuel quantity indicating systems is that the indicator
Answer A: can be located any distance from the tank(s).
Answer C: always measures volume instead of mass.
Explanation (General): Most modern aircraft use electrical or electronic fuel-quantity-indicating systems because of the ease with which the indicator can be located a distance from the fuel tanks.

Question: When fuel quantity is measured in pounds instead of gallons, the measurement will be more accurate because fuel volume
Answer C: varies with changes in atmospheric pressure.
Explanation (General): An indication of the weight of the fuel in an aircraft fuel tank is more important than a measure of its volume. The engine uses the fuel on the basis of its weight, and the volume of the fuel in the tanks changes as the temperature of the fuel changes.

Question: An electrical-type fuel quantity indicating system consists of an indicator in the cockpit and a
Answer A: float-operated transmitter installed in the tank.
Answer B: float resting on the surface of the tank.
Answer C: float-operated receiver installed in the tank.
Explanation (General): An electrical fuel-quantity-indicating system uses a float-operated transmitter in the fuel tank to furnish information to the indicator on the instrument panel. The transmitter is normally a float-operated variable resistor.

Question: What is the purpose of a float-operated transmitter installed in a fuel tank?
Answer A: It sends an electric signal to the fuel quantity indicator.
Answer B: It senses the total amount of fuel density.
Answer C: It senses the dielectric qualities of fuel and air in the tank.
Explanation (General): A float-operated, fuel-quantity transmitter is normally a variable resistor whose resistance changes with the fuel level in the tank. Information on the fuel level is sent as an electrical signal to the fuel-quantity indicator on the instrument panel.

Question: In an electronic-type fuel quantity indicating system, the tank sensing unit is a
Answer C: variable inductor.
Explanation (General): The fuel-tank transmitters in an electronic-type fuel quantity indicating system are capacitors.|A tank probe (transmitter) is made of two concentric metal tubes that act as the plates of a capacitor. The fuel in the tank and the air above the fuel act as the dielectric. The capacitance of the probe is determined by the relative amount of fuel and air between the plates.

Question: What must each fuel quantity indicator be calibrated to read during level flight when the quantity of fuel remaining is equal to the unusable fuel supply?
Answer B: Both the total unusable fuel quantity and the unusable fuel quantity in each tank.
Answer C: Zero.
Explanation (General): Each fuel quantity indicator must be calibrated to read 'zero' during level flight when the quantity of the fuel remaining in the tank is equal to the unusable fuel supply.

Question: What unit would be adjusted to change the fuel pressure warning limits?
Answer C: Fuel pressure relief valve.
Explanation (General): The contacts on the pressure-sensitive mechanism would be adjusted to change the pressure at which the fuel-pressure-warning unit actuates.

Question: Select one means of controlling the fuel temperature on turbine-powered aircraft.
Answer A: Engine bleed air to the fuel filter.
Answer B: Engine bleed air to the fuel tank.
Answer C: Engine bleed air to a heat exchanger.
Explanation (General): Ice is prevented from clogging the filter of a turbine-powered aircraft fuel system by routing warm compressor bleed air through an air-to-fuel heat exchanger.|All of the fuel that flows to the engine must pass through this heat exchanger.

Question: What is the purpose of flapper-type check valves in integral fuel tanks?
Answer A: To allow defueling of the tanks by suction.
Answer B: To prevent fuel from flowing away from the boost pumps.
Answer C: To allow the engine-driven pumps to draw fuel directly from the tank if the boost pump fails.
Explanation (General): Some integral fuel tanks have flapper-type check valves that allow fuel to flow to the booster pump, but prevent rough air or abrupt flight maneuvers from causing the fuel to flow away from the booster pump.|Some aircraft also have a pump-removal, flapper-type check valve that allows a booster pump to be removed from the tank without having to first drain the tank.

Question: What unit is generally used to actuate the fuel pressure warning system?
Answer C: Fuel pressure gauge.
Explanation (General): A pressure-sensitive mechanism (generally a bellows) is used to actuate the fuel-pressure-warning system.

Question: What method is used on turbine-powered aircraft to determine when the condition of the fuel is approaching the danger of forming ice crystals?
Answer C: Fuel temperature indicator.
Explanation (General): Fuel-temperature-indicating systems are required in turbine aircraft to warn when there is danger of ice crystals forming in the fuel.|A fuel-strainer differential pressure gauge gives an indication that ice crystals have already formed and are restricting the fuel filter. Ice crystals on the filter element cause an excessive pressure drop across the filter.

Question: Which of the following would give the first positive indication that a change-over from one fuel tank to another is needed?
Answer C: Fuel quantity indicator.
Explanation (General): The fuel-pressure-warning system should give the first indication, by a loss of pressure, that a fuel tank is empty. This drop in pressure warns the pilot to switch to a full tank.

Question: A fuel pressure warning switch contacts close and warning light is turned on when
Answer A: a measured quantity of fuel has passed through it.
Answer C: the fuel pressure drops below specified limits.
Explanation (General): The fuel-pressure-warning-switch contacts close and a warning light turns on when the fuel pressure drops below a specified limit.

Question: A transmitter in a fuel pressure warning system serves what function?
Answer A: Transmits an electrical signal to fluid pressure.
Answer B: Converts fluid pressure to an electrical signal.
Answer C: Transmits fluid pressure directly to the indicator.
Explanation (General): The transmitter in a fuel-pressure-warning system converts the pressure of the fuel into an electrical signal that turns on a warning light or flashes a warning on an annunciator panel.

Question: Where is fuel pressure taken for the pressure warning signal on most aircraft engines?
Answer A: Outlet side of the boost pump.
Answer B: Fuel pressure line of the carburetor.
Answer C: Between the fuel pump and the strainer.
Explanation (General): The fuel-pressure-warning signal used with most aircraft engines is taken from the fuel-pressure line that goes to the fuel inlet of the carburetor.

Question: Which of the following is necessary to effectively troubleshoot a fuel pressure warning system?
Answer B: AC 43.13-1B, Acceptable Methods, Techniques, and Practices -- Aircraft Inspection and Repair.
Answer C: A set of Federal Aviation Regulations.
Explanation (General): The manufacturer's maintenance manuals give all the information needed to effectively troubleshoot a fuel-pressure-warning system.

Question: Which of the following would be most useful to locate and troubleshoot an internal fuel leak in an aircraft fuel system?
Answer C: A fuel system schematic.
Explanation (General): A schematic diagram of the fuel system furnishes the most useful information to help in locating and troubleshooting an internal fuel leak in an aircraft fuel system.

Question: In some aircraft with several fuel tanks, the possible danger of allowing the fuel supply in one tank to become exhausted before the selector valve is switched to another tank is prevented by the installation of
Answer A: a fuel pressure warning signal system.
Answer C: an engine fuel pump bypass valve.
Explanation (General): Fuel-pressure-warning-signal systems are installed in many large aircraft to warn the pilot or flight engineer that a tank has been emptied and a full tank should be selected.

Question: (1) The function of a fuel heater is to protect the engine fuel system from ice formation.|(2) An aircraft fuel heater cannot be used to thaw ice in the fuel screen.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer C: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. The function of a fuel heater is to protect the engine-fuel system from ice formation.|Statement (2) is not true. A fuel heater can be used to thaw ice that has formed on the fuel screen.

Question: (1) Gas-turbine-engine fuel systems are very susceptible to the formation of ice in the fuel filters.|(2) A fuel heater operates as a heat exchanger to warm the fuel.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer C: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. Gas-turbine-engine fuel systems are very susceptible to the formation of ice on the fuel filters.|Statement (2) is also true. The fuel heater operates as a heat exchanger to warm the fuel. These heat exchangers may use engine compressor bleed air or warm engine oil to furnish the heat.

Question: (1) A fuel heater can use engine bleed air as a source of heat.|(2) A fuel heater can use engine lubricating oil as a source of heat.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer B: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Answer C: neither No. 1 nor No. 2 is true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. A fuel heater can use engine bleed air as a source of heat.|Statement (2) is also true. A fuel heater can use engine lubricating oil as a source of heat.

Question: (1) A fuel pressure gauge is a differential pressure indicator.|(2) A fuel pressure gauge indicates the pressure of the fuel entering the carburetor.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer B: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Answer C: neither No. 1 nor No. 2 is true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. Most fuel-pressure gauges are differential pressure gauges. They measure the difference in the pressure of the fuel and the pressure of some reference air. When a pressure carburetor is used, this reference air pressure is the carburetor upper-deck air pressure.|Statement (2) is also true. The pressure shown on the gauge is the pressure of the fuel as it enters the carburetor.

Question: (1) A fuel pressure relief valve is required on an aircraft positive-displacement fuel pump.|(2) A fuel pressure relief valve is required on an aircraft centrifugal fuel boost pump.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer C: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. A pressure-relief valve is required for a positive-displacement aircraft fuel pump.|Statement (2) is not true. A pressure-relief valve is not needed with a centrifugal fuel boost pump.

Question: The primary purpose of a fuel tank sump is to provide a
Answer A: positive system of maintaining the design minimum fuel supply for safe operation.
Answer B: place where water and dirt accumulations in the tank can collect and be drained.
Answer C: reserve supply of fuel to enable the aircraft to land safely in the event of fuel exhaustion.
Explanation (General): Fuel tanks are equipped with sumps (low points in the tank) in which water and dirt will accumulate to be collected and drained.

Question: Why are integral fuel tanks used in many large aircraft?
Answer C: To reduce weight.
Explanation (General): Integral fuel tanks are used in large aircraft to reduce weight and to utilize as much of the space as possible for carrying fuel.

Question: If an aircraft is fueled from a truck or storage tank which is known to be uncontaminated with dirt or water, periodic checks of the aircraft's fuel tank sumps and system strainers
Answer A: can be eliminated except for the strainer check before the first flight of the day and the fuel tank sump check during 100-hour or annual inspections.
Answer B: are still necessary due to the possibility of contamination from other sources.
Answer C: can be sharply reduced since contamination from other sources is relatively unlikely and of little consequence in modern aircraft fuel systems.
Explanation (General): Even though an aircraft is fueled from an uncontaminated source, the fuel tank sumps and strainers must be periodically checked, as there is always the possibility of contamination from other sources.

Question: Aircraft defueling should be accomplished
Answer A: with the aircraft's communication equipment on and in contact with the tower in case of fire.
Answer B: in a hangar where activities can be controlled.
Answer C: in the open air for good ventilation.
Explanation (General): Both fueling and defueling operations should be conducted in the open air where there is good ventilation.

Question: Integral fuel tanks on transport aircraft are
Answer C: formed by the aircraft structure.
Explanation (General): Integral fuel tanks are actually a part of the aircraft structure in which all of the seams and riveted joints are sealed with an appropriate sealant.|The fuel is carried in the sealed-off aircraft structure.

Question: What precautions must be observed if a gravity-feed fuel system is permitted to supply fuel to an engine from more than one tank at a time?
Answer A: The tank airspaces must be interconnected.
Answer B: The fuel outlet ports of each tank must have the same cross-sectional area.
Answer C: Each tank must have a valve in its outlet that automatically shuts off the line when the tank is empty.
Explanation (General): If a gravity-feed fuel system is permitted to supply fuel to an engine from more than one tank at a time, the air space above the fuel in the tanks must be interconnected.

Question: The purpose of the baffle plate in a fuel tank is to
Answer A: provide an expansion space for the fuel.
Answer B: resist fuel surging within the fuel tank.
Answer C: provide internal structural integrity.
Explanation (General): Baffle plates in a fuel tank resist (prevent) the fuel from surging in the tank.

Question: What minimum required markings must be placed on or near each appropriate fuel filler cover on utility category aircraft?
Answer A: The word 'Avgas' and the minimum fuel grade, and the total fuel tank capacity.
Answer B: The word 'Avgas' and the minimum fuel grade or designation for the engines, and the usable fuel tank capacity.
Answer C: The word 'Avgas' and the minimum fuel grade.
Explanation (General): 14 CFR 23.1557 states that the fuel filler openings on a reciprocating-engine-powered airplane must be marked at or near the filler cover with the word 'Avgas' and the minimum fuel grade.|If the airplane is turbine-engine-powered, the markings must include the words 'Jet Fuel' and the permissible fuel designations or reference to the Airplane Flight Manual (AFM) for permissible fuel designations.

Question: What is one disadvantage of using aromatic aviation fuels?
Answer C: Results in low fuel volatility.
Explanation (General): Aromatic additives in aviation gasoline increase its antidetonation characteristics, but they also cause deterioration of rubber parts.|Any hose, seal, or diaphragm used with a fuel that contains aromatic additives must be specifically formulated to withstand these additives.

Question: Fuel-boost pumps are operated
Answer A: to provide a positive flow of fuel to the engine.
Answer C: automatically from fuel pressure.
Explanation (General): Fuel boost pumps are used to provide a positive flow of fuel from the tank to the engine.|Boost pumps are used for engine starting, as a backup for takeoff and landing, and in many cases, to transfer fuel from one tank to another.

Question: Flapper valves are used in fuel tanks to
Answer C: act as check valves.
Explanation (General): Flapper valves are used in fuel tanks to serve as check valves.|Flapper valves allow fuel to flow to the booster pump but prevent its flowing away from the pump during certain flight maneuvers.

Question: Why are centrifugal-type boost pumps used in fuel systems of aircraft operating at high altitude?
Answer A: Because they are positive displacement pumps.
Answer B: To supply fuel under pressure to engine-driven pumps.
Answer C: To permit cooling air to circulate around the motor.
Explanation (General): Centrifugal boost pumps are used in the fuel tanks of aircraft that operate at high altitude.|Boost pumps supply fuel under positive pressure to the inlet of the engine-driven fuel pumps under conditions where the ambient pressure is too low to ensure a positive supply.

Question: Why is it necessary to vent all aircraft fuel tanks?
Answer A: To ensure a positive head pressure for a submerged boost pump.
Answer C: To limit pressure differential between the tank and atmosphere.
Explanation (General): According to 14 CFR 23.975, fuel tanks must be vented with the vents having sufficient capacity to allow the rapid relief of excessive pressure between the interior and the exterior of the tank.

Question: According to Part 23, what minimum required markings must be placed at or near each appropriate fuel filler cover for reciprocating engine-powered airplanes?
Answer A: The word 'Avgas' and the minimum fuel grade.
Answer B: The word 'Fuel' and usable fuel capacity.
Answer C: The word 'Avgas' and the total fuel capacity.
Explanation (General): According to 14 CFR 23.1557, fuel filler openings for reciprocating engine-powered airplanes must be marked at or near the filler cover with the word 'Avgas,' and the minimum fuel grade.

Question: The location of leaks and defects within the internal portions of the fuel system can usually be determined by
Answer A: visual inspection for evidence of wet spots and stains, and feeling for unusually warm components.
Answer C: observing the pressure gauge and operating the selector valves.
Explanation (General): It is possible, by watching the fuel-pressure gauge and operating the selector valves, to isolate a portion of a large-aircraft fuel system that has an internal leak.

Question: What type of fuel-booster pump requires a pressure relief valve?
Answer C: Centrifugal.
Explanation (General): A sliding-vane fuel pump requires a pressure-relief valve because it is a constant-displacement pump.

Question: To prevent vapor lock in fuel lines at high altitude, some aircraft are equipped with
Answer C: booster pumps.
Explanation (General): Booster pumps are installed in the fuel tanks of some aircraft to prevent vapor lock in the fuel lines at high altitudes.|The booster pump holds a positive pressure on the fuel in the lines, between the tank and the engine-driven fuel pump.

Question: A fuel temperature indicator is located in the fuel tanks on some turbine-powered airplanes to tell when the fuel may be
Answer A: getting cold enough to form hard ice.
Answer B: in danger of forming ice crystals.
Answer C: about to form rime ice.
Explanation (General): Fuel-temperature sensors (fuel-temperature indicators) are installed in the fuel tanks of some jet-powered aircraft to show the flight engineer the temperature of the fuel.|By knowing the temperature of the fuel in the tanks, the flight engineer can know when there is danger of ice crystals forming in the fuel and blocking the fuel strainers.

Question: When inspecting a fuel system, you should check all valves located downstream of boost pumps with the pumps
Answer C: operating.
Explanation (General): In order to inspect a fuel system for leaks, you should inspect all of the valves located downstream of the booster pump, with the pumps operating and producing maximum pressure.

Question: The type of fuel-boost pump that separates air and vapor from the fuel before it enters the line to the carburetor is the
Answer C: sliding vane-type pump.
Explanation (General): Centrifugal boost pumps normally have a small agitator (a small propeller) that spins when the pump impeller is turning to separate the vapor from the fuel before the fuel enters the lines to the carburetor.

Question: (1) On a large aircraft pressure refueling system, a pressure refueling receptacle and control panel will permit one person to fuel or defuel any or all fuel tanks of an aircraft.|(2) Because of the fuel tank area, there are more advantages to a pressure fueling system in light aircraft.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer C: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. Large aircraft pressure-fueling systems consist of a refueling receptacle and a panel of controls and gauges that permit one person to fuel or defuel any or all fuel tanks of an aircraft.|Statement (2) is not true. Because of the limited fuel tank area, there are fewer advantages of a pressure-fueling system in light aircraft.

Question: When routing a fuel line between two rigidly mounted fittings the line should
Answer A: have at least one bend between such fittings.
Answer B: be a straight length of tubing and clamped to the aircraft structure.
Answer C: have a flexible line added between two metal lines to allow for ease of installation.
Explanation (General): Never install a straight length of tubing between two rigidly mounted fittings. Always incorporate at least one bend between such fittings to absorb strain caused by vibration and temperature changes.

Question: (1) If aviation gasoline vaporizes too readily, fuel lines may become filled with vapor and cause increased fuel flow.|(2) A measure of a gasoline's tendency to vapor lock is obtained from the Reid vapor pressure test.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer B: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Answer C: neither No. 1 nor No. 2 is true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is not true. If the gasoline vaporizes too readily, fuel lines may become filled with vapor and cause decreased, not increased, fuel flow.|Statement (2) is true. The Reid vapor pressure of a fuel is a measure of the fuel's tendency to vapor lock.

Question: Microbial growth is produced by various forms of microorganisms that live and multiply in the water interfaces of jet fuels. Which of the following could result if microbial growth exists in a jet fuel tank and is not corrected?|1. Interference with fuel flow.|2. Interference with fuel quantity indicators.|3. Engine seizure.|4. Electrolytic corrosive action in a metal tank.|5. Lower grade rating of the fuel.|6. Electrolytic corrosive action in a rubber tank.
Explanation (General): The buildup of micro-organisms in the fuel tank of a jet aircraft can not only interfere with fuel flow and with the fuel quantity indicators, but more importantly, can start electrolytic corrosion in metal fuel tanks.

Question: The vapor pressure of aviation gasoline is
Answer A: lower than the vapor pressure of automotive gasoline.
Answer B: higher than the vapor pressure of automotive gasoline.
Answer C: approximately 20 PSI at 100__degrees__F.
Explanation (General): The vapor pressure of aviation gasoline is limited to a maximum of 7 psi, which is lower than the vapor pressure of many grades of automobile gasoline.

Question: What can be done to eliminate or minimize the microbial growth problem in an aircraft jet fuel tank?
Answer C: Keep the fuel tank topped off.
Explanation (General): An anti-icing and antibacterial additive is often used in jet aircraft fuel tanks to minimize the problems caused by microbial growth inside the fuel tanks.

Question: What is the maximum vapor pressure allowable for an aircraft fuel?
Answer C: 3 PSI.
Explanation (General): A Reid vapor pressure of 7 psi at 100__degrees__F is the maximum allowed for aviation gasoline.

Question: If a bladder-type fuel tank is to be left empty for an extended period of time, the inside of the tank should be coated with a film of
Answer C: ethylene glycol.
Explanation (General): If a rubberized fabric bladder tank is to remain empty for an extended period of time, it should be cleaned out thoroughly and its interior covered with a film of clean engine oil.

Question: How may the antiknock characteristics of a fuel be improved?
Answer C: By adding a fungicide agent.
Explanation (General): The antiknock characteristics of a fuel may be improved by adding a knock inhibitor such as tetraethyl lead to the fuel.

Question: Some electric motors have two sets of field windings wound in opposite directions so that the
Answer A: speed of the motor can be more closely controlled.
Answer B: power output of the motor can be more closely controlled.
Answer C: motor can be operated in either direction.
Explanation (General): Reversible DC motors have two sets of field windings wound in opposite directions.|By using two sets of windings, the direction of the armature rotation can be reversed by the action of a switch.

Question: One purpose of a growler test is to determine the presence of
Answer C: a shorted armature.
Explanation (General): A growler test may be made of an armature to determine if any of the windings are shorted.

Question: Electric wire terminals for most aircraft applications must be what type?
Answer C: Ring.
Explanation (General): Most aircraft electrical wiring is terminated with ring-type terminals rather than hook or slotted terminals. If the nut on the terminal stud should become loose, the ring-type terminal will remain on the stud whereas a hook or slotted terminal will slip off.

Question: What is the principal advantage of the series-wound dc motor?
Answer C: Low starting torque.
Explanation (General): One of the chief characteristics, or advantages, of a series-wound DC motor is its high starting torque.

Question: If a generator is equipped with a vibrator-type voltage regulator, the actual time the voltage regulator points remain open
Answer A: depends on the load carried by the generator.
Answer B: is controlled by the reverse-current cutout relay point clearance.
Answer C: is increased when the external load is greater than the generator output.
Explanation (General): The actual time the voltage-regulator points in a vibrator-type voltage regulator remain open is determined by the amount of load being carried by the generator.|When the load is great, the voltage drops and the points must remain closed longer to allow the voltage to rise.|When the load is light, the voltage is high and the points remain closed a very short time.

Question: What is a cause of generator brush arcing?
Answer C: Low spring tension.
Explanation (General): Low spring tension on generator brushes could cause the brushes to bounce and arc.

Question: What is required when operating two aircraft ac generators in parallel?
Answer A: Amperes and frequency must both be equal.
Answer B: Frequency and voltage must both be equal.
Answer C: Amperes and voltage must both be equal.
Explanation (General): Before AC generators may be connected in parallel, it must be determined that the output voltage, the frequency, and the phase rotation of all the generators are the same.

Question: The starting current of a series-wound dc motor, in passing through both the field and armature windings, produces a
Answer C: high starting torque.
Explanation (General): A series-wound DC motor has a very high starting torque because all of the current that passes through the armature also passes through the field.

Question: Which motor would be most likely to have an armature brake?
Answer C: Inverter drive motor.
Explanation (General): A landing-light retraction motor is the most likely of the motors listed here to have an armature brake.|The brake causes the armature to stop turning as soon as the switch is released.

Question: The method most often used in overcoming the effect of armature reaction is through the use of
Answer C: drum-wound armatures in combination with a negatively connected series field.
Explanation (General): Interpoles are used in large compound-wound DC generators to overcome the effect of armature reaction.|If armature reaction is not corrected, it will cause the brushes to arc under certain load conditions.

Question: The only practical method of maintaining a constant voltage output from an aircraft generator under varying conditions of speed and load is to vary the
Answer B: number of conductors in the armature.
Answer C: speed at which the armature rotates.
Explanation (General): A constant generator output voltage is maintained under varying load and speed conditions by varying the strength of the magnetic field in the generator.

Question: The pole pieces or shoes used in a dc generator are a part of the
Answer C: brush assembly.
Explanation (General): The pole pieces (pole shoes) in a DC generator are part of the field assembly. The pole pieces form a part of the magnetic circuit for the field.

Question: How many cycles of ac voltage are produced in a six-pole alternator of the revolving-field type for each revolution of the rotor?
Answer C: Six.
Explanation (General): Three cycles of alternating current are produced by a six-pole alternator for each revolution of the rotor. Each pair of poles produces one cycle of AC.

Question: If the reverse current cutout relay contact points fail to open after the generator output has dropped below battery potential, current will flow through the generator armature
Answer A: in the normal direction and through the shunt field opposite the normal direction.
Answer B: and the shunt field opposite the normal direction.
Answer C: opposite the normal direction and through the shunt field in the normal direction.
Explanation (General): If the reverse-current-cutout relay contacts fail to open when the generator output drops below the battery potential, current will flow from the battery through the armature in the direction opposite its normal flow.|Current will also flow through the shunt field but it will flow through the field coils in the normal direction of flow.

Question: How does the magnetic brake used to stop rotation of an electric motor armature operate?
Answer A: Centrifugal force releases a rotating brake cog from a stationary notch when the armature reaches a certain speed and magnetic force re-engages the cog when the electrical power is turned off.
Answer B: A friction brake is applied by a magnet and released by a spring.
Answer C: A friction brake is applied by a spring and released by a magnet.
Explanation (General): A magnetic brake used to stop rotation of an electric-motor armature is applied by spring force and is released by an electromagnet energized when the motor is turned on.|As soon as the motor is turned off, the spring applies the brake and stops the rotation of the armature.

Question: In a generator, what eliminates any possible sparking to the brush guides caused by the movement of the brushes within the holder?
Answer C: Undercutting the mica on the commutator.
Explanation (General): The brush pigtail eliminates any possible sparking between the brush and the brush guide.|All of the current is carried from the brush into the holder through the pigtail rather than through the sliding contact made between the brush and the brush guide.

Question: A series-wound dc electric motor will normally require
Answer A: more current at high RPM than at low RPM.
Answer B: approximately the same current throughout its operating range of speed.
Answer C: more current at low RPM than at high RPM.
Explanation (General): A series-wound DC motor produces an extremely high starting torque. It uses a large amount of current when it first starts to rotate and when it is operating at slow speeds. The current drops off as the armature speed and the counter EMF builds up.

Question: The type of electric wire terminals used for most aircraft applications, in addition to providing good current carrying capabilities, are designed primarily
Answer A: to prevent circuit failure due to terminal disconnection.
Answer B: for uncomplicated and rapid circuit connection and disconnection.
Answer C: for permanent connection to the circuit.
Explanation (General): Terminals used on aircraft electrical wires must safely carry all of the current the wire can carry. They must also be designed in such a way that they cannot cause a circuit failure by inadvertently disconnecting from the terminal on which they are installed.

Question: Aluminum wire must be stripped very carefully because
Answer A: high resistance will develop in stripping nicks.
Answer B: stripping nicks can cause short circuits.
Answer C: individual strands will break easily after being nicked.
Explanation (General): Aluminum wire must be stripped very carefully, because if a strand is nicked, it will quite likely break.

Question: The commutator of a generator
Answer A: changes direct current produced in the armature into alternating current as it is taken from the armature.
Answer B: changes alternating current produced in the armature into direct current as it is taken from the armature.
Answer C: reverses the current in the field coils at the proper time in order to produce direct current.
Explanation (General): The commutator and the brushes used on a DC generator acts as a mechanical rectifier that changes the AC produced in the armature coils into DC before it leaves the generator.

Question: An ammeter in a battery charging system is for the purpose of indicating the
Answer B: total amperes being used in the airplane.
Answer C: rate of current used to charge the battery.
Explanation (General): An ammeter in a battery-charging circuit in an aircraft is used to indicate the rate of current that flows into or out of the battery.

Question: Which of the following is not one of the purposes of interpoles in a generator?
Answer C: Reduce arcing at the brushes.
Explanation (General): Interpoles are used in high-output compound-wound DC generators to counteract field distortion and to overcome armature reaction. Armature reaction causes arcing at the brushes.|Interpoles do not reduce the field strength, they increase it.

Question: To test generator or motor armature windings for opens,
Answer A: place armature in a growler and connect a 110V test light on adjacent segments; light should light.
Answer B: check adjacent segments on commutator with an ohmmeter on the high resistance scale.
Answer C: use a 12/24V test light between the armature core segments and the shaft.
Explanation (General): A generator armature may be checked for an open winding by placing it on a growler and using the built-in 110-volt test lamp to test for continuity between the individual segments.|The lamp will light if the coil between the segments being checked is good.

Question: What is the color and orientation of the position lights for navigation on civil airplanes?
Answer A: Left side - green, right side - red, rear aft - white.
Answer B: Left side - red, right side - green, rear aft - white.
Answer C: Left side - white, right side - green, rear aft - red.
Explanation (General): Position lights for navigation on an aircraft are located on the wing tips and the tail. There is a red light on the left wing, a green light on the right wing, and a white light on the tail that shines aft.

Question: To what depth is the mica insulation between the commutator bars of a dc generator undercut?
Answer A: One-half the width of the mica.
Answer B: Equal to twice the width of the mica.
Answer C: Equal to the width of the mica.
Explanation (General): When a DC generator is overhauled, the commutator is turned on a lathe until it is perfectly round and smooth.|After the commutator is turned, the mica separators between the commutator bars are undercut to approximately the width of the mica, or somewhere in the neighborhood of 0.02 inch.

Question: A voltage regulator controls generator output by
Answer A: introducing a resistance in generator-to-battery lead in the event of overload.
Answer B: shorting out field coil in the event of overload.
Answer C: varying current flow to generator field coil.
Explanation (General): A voltage regulator controls generator output voltage by varying the amount of current allowed to flow in the generator field coil.

Question: Which type of dc generator is not used as an airplane generator?
Answer C: Compound wound.
Explanation (General): Series-wound DC generators are not used in aircraft electrical systems because of the difficulty in regulating and controlling the output voltage.

Question: What is the most accurate type of frequency-measuring instrument?
Answer A: Integrated circuit chip having a clock circuit.
Answer C: Electromagnets using one permanent magnet.
Explanation (General): The most accurate frequency-measuring instruments in use today are digital instruments that contain integrated-circuit chips and a clock circuit.

Question: During ground operation, aircraft generator cooling is usually accomplished by
Answer A: auxiliary air cooled through an air/fuel heat exchanger.
Answer C: an external motor-driven fan.
Explanation (General): When an aircraft is operating on the ground, the generator is cooled by air pulled through its windings by an integral fan (a fan that is mounted on the armature shaft).

Question: What does a rectifier do?
Answer A: Changes direct current into alternating current.
Answer B: Changes alternating current into direct current.
Answer C: Reduces voltage.
Explanation (General): A rectifier is an electrical device or circuit that allows electrons to pass in one direction but blocks them when they try to flow in the opposite direction.|A rectifier changes alternating current into direct current.

Question: What type of instrument is used for measuring very high values of resistance?
Answer C: Multimeter.
Explanation (General): A megohmmeter is a special type of ohmmeter used to measure very high values of resistance.|Many megohmmeters have their own high-voltage power supply built into them.

Question: When a diode is checked for an open circuit or a short circuit, it should be
Answer C: disconnected from the circuit.
Explanation (General): When a semiconductor diode is checked for an open or a short circuit, it is removed from the circuit and its resistance is checked with an ohmmeter.|The diode is good if it has a high resistance when checked in one direction and a low resistance when it is checked in the opposite direction.|The diode is shorted if both readings are low, and it is open if both readings are high.

Question: When handling a high voltage capacitor in an electrical circuit, be sure it
Answer A: has a full charge before removing it from the circuit.
Answer B: has at least a residual charge before removing it from the circuit.
Answer C: is fully discharged before removing it from the circuit.
Explanation (General): A high-voltage capacitor can store enough electrical charge to cause a dangerous shock when it is removed from the circuit. Before removing any high-voltage capacitor, short across its terminals with an insulated-handle screwdriver to fully discharge it.

Question: Which of the following is most likely to cause thermal runaway in a nickel-cadmium battery?
Answer B: Excessive current draw from the battery.
Answer C: Constant current charging of the battery to more than 100 percent of its capacity.
Explanation (General): Thermal runaway of a nickel-cadmium battery occurs when some of the cells become excessively hot. The heat lowers both the voltage and the resistance so the cells can accept a high rate of charging current. This high current produces more heat and the battery can destroy itself.|The temperature rise that triggers the thermal problems can come from heat generated by a fast discharge, from high ambient temperature, or from a breakdown of the separator material.

Question: How can it be determined if a transformer winding has some of its turns shorted together?
Answer A: Measure the input voltage with an ohmmeter.
Answer B: The output voltage will be high.
Answer C: The transformer will get hot in normal operation.
Explanation (General): If some of the windings in a transformer are shorted together, an excessive amount of current will flow in the windings and the transformer will get hot in normal operation.

Question: Which of the following are the major parts of a dc motor?|1. Armature assembly.|2. Field assembly.|3. Brush assembly.|4. Commutator.|5. Pole piece.|6. Rheostat.|7. End frame.
Explanation (General): The major parts of a practical DC motor are the armature assembly, the field assembly, the brush assembly, and the end frame.

Question: (1) There are three basic types of dc motors; series, shunt, and compound.|(2) In the series motor, the field windings, consisting of relatively few turns of heavy wire, are connected in series with the armature winding.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer C: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. There are three basic types of DC motors: series motors, shunt motors, and compound motors.|Statement (2) is also true. In a series motor, the field windings, consisting of a relatively few turns of heavy wire, are connected in series with the armature winding.

Question: For general electrical use in aircraft, the acceptable method of attaching a terminal to a wire is by
Answer C: crimping and soldering.
Explanation (General): Crimped terminals on an aircraft electrical wire transmit the tension and vibration loads from the wire into the terminal gradually and do not cause stress concentrations, as is done with a soldered connection. Soldered terminals are not considered satisfactory for aircraft wiring because vibration will likely cause them to break off of the wire.

Question: Which of the following factors must be taken into consideration when determining the wire size to use for an aircraft installation?|1. Mechanical strength.|2. Allowable power loss.|3. Ease of installation.|4. Resistance of current return path through the aircraft structure.|5. Permissible voltage drop.|6. Current carrying capability of the conductor.|7. Type of load (continuous or intermittent).
